product-overview.heading: Digital Certificate Generation & Sharing System
body: Developed an online certificate issuance system that allows students to instantly receive and share their certificates digitally.

Each certificate includes a QR code, which redirects users to a public certificate verification page, enabling students to share verified certificates on platforms like LinkedIn, Facebook, and X (Twitter).

numberedItems.title: Client → API → Server → Database (phpMyAdmin)
numberedItems.description: Student information is submitted and stored in the database.

numberedItems.title: Server → Cloudinary
numberedItems.description: Generated certificate images are uploaded to Cloudinary for public access.

numberedItems.title: Certificate Page
numberedItems.description: The system dynamically creates QR-code-embedded certificates using CSS and PDF-lib.

numberedItems.title: Sharing Feature
numberedItems.description: Share buttons for LinkedIn, Facebook, and X are implemented. Facebook requires special configuration for Facebook Crawler Requests to display preview images.

constraints--trade-offs.heading: Tech stack
body: Why Vue 3: Vue 3 offered a lightweight and flexible structure, especially for building reactive certificate forms and maintaining fast performance through Vite's dev server.

processBlocks.title: 1. Blob-to-JPEG Conversion in a Serverless Environment

items.title: 1. Converting PDF to JPEG using Poppler (Initial Attempt)
items.body: Converting PDF blobs to JPEG in a serverless environment (Vercel) was challenging. Initial attempt using Poppler (node-poppler) failed because Vercel does not support native binaries (.so, .dll), making it unsuitable for a serverless environment.

items.title: 2. Generating the Diploma with CSS (Second Attempt)
items.body: A second attempt used CSS for the diploma layout and Puppeteer (a Node.js library for headless Chrome) to convert styled HTML to PDF. PDF generation worked but the rendered images appeared blurry and pixelated in the browser, making it unsuitable for production.

subsections.heading: Solution:
body: Conversion was moved to the frontend using PDF-lib and Canvas to generate a Base64 image, which was then uploaded to Cloudinary as a JPEG via the Express API. This removed native dependencies and ensured compatibility with Vercel's serverless runtime.

processBlocks.title: 2. Optimizing File Upload Workflow After Conversion

subsections.heading: Challenge:
body: Initially, I planned to upload the generated image to the WordPress Media API, since all student data was stored in WordPress. However, direct upload attempts from the Express server consistently failed due to CORS and authentication restrictions.

subsections.heading: Solution:
body: I switched to Cloudinary, which provides a reliable and developer-friendly API for direct uploads. Using cloudinary.uploader.upload_stream(), I could efficiently upload the converted certificate image and receive a public URL for display. This allowed seamless integration with both the backend (phpMyAdmin) and frontend certificate page.

processBlocks.title: 3. Implementing Server-Side OG Tag Rendering for Facebook Previews

subsections.heading: Challenge:
body: When sharing the certificate page on social platforms, LinkedIn and X (Twitter) displayed the preview image correctly, but Facebook did not. This happened because Facebook's crawler does not execute JavaScript — it only reads the static HTML and checks for Open Graph (OG) meta tags. Since my app was a Single Page Application (SPA) built with Vue, those tags were injected client-side and invisible to Facebook's crawler.

subsections.heading: Solution:
body: I implemented a dedicated server route (for example, /api/certificates/share/:id) that returns pre-rendered HTML containing the correct Open Graph meta tags, including og:image, og:title, and og:description, as well as a link to the public certificate page. Social platforms like Facebook and LinkedIn don't run JavaScript; they simply fetch the initial HTML for the shared URL and scan it for tags. In a typical SPA, those tags are injected client-side and are therefore invisible to the crawler. By moving the OG tags into a server-rendered endpoint that directly includes the Cloudinary image URL, Facebook was able to read the metadata correctly, show the certificate preview image, and redirect users to the public certificate page when they clicked the preview.

Debugging style inheritance conflicts across frameworks.
